This introduction is not part of IEEE Std 1522-2004.
IEEE Trial-Use Standard for Testability and Diagnosability Characteristics and Metrics is not part of this introduction.
Systems became more complex costly and difficult to diagnose and repair.
Initiatives were started to address these problems.
The objective of one initiative was to make systems easier to test.
This commercial standard must provide specific unambiguous definitions of criteria for assessing system testability.
IEEE has started initiatives to standardize test architectures.

The IEEE 1232TM Artificial Intelligence Exchange and Service Tie to All Test Environments series of standards provide the foundation for precise and unambiguous testability and diagnosability metrics.

The IEEE 1232TM Artificial Intelligence Exchange and Service Tie to All Test Environments series of standards provide the foundation for precise and unambiguous testability and diagnosability metrics.
It is the objective of this standard to provide notionally correct and inherently useful but mathematically precise definitions of testability measures.
Notionally correct means that the measures are not in conflict with intuitive and historical representations.

IEEE Trial-Use Standard for Testability and Diagnosability Characteristics and Metrics was developed by the Diagnostic and Maintenance Control subcommittee of the IEEE Standards Coordinating Committee 20 on Test and Diagnosis for Electronic Systems.
the standard provides standard unambiguous definitions of testability and diagnosability metrics and characteristics.
the standard builds on fundamental definitions derived from elements in formal information models related to test and diagnosis defined in IEEE Std 1232TM-2002.
the standard provides definitions of testability and diagnosability characteristics and metrics that are independent of specific test and diagnosis technologies.
the standard provides definitions of testability and diagnosability characteristics and metrics that are independent of specific system under test technologies.
the standard provides unambiguous definitions of testability and diagnosability metrics used by procurement and support organizations.
Lord Kelvin commented that when you can measure what you are speaking about and express it in numbers, you know something about it.
Lord Kelvin commented that when you cannot measure it, you cannot express it in numbers, your knowledge is of a meager and unsatisfactory kind.
when different tools measure something differently, and the basis for the measurement is not known or understood, it is neither knowledge nor science.
the objective of this standard is to provide precise formal definitions of metrics that may be used to predict the testability of a system.

Faults in a system should be localized frequently and unambiguously.
Fault localization in a system should be optimized.
Faults in a system should be detected and isolated during operation and maintenance.
Fault isolation in a system should be performed efficiently.
Fault isolation in a system should be performed in a timely manner.
System design should include characteristics to make the system easier to test.
Testability is a design characteristic that allows the status of an item to be determined.
Testability is a design characteristic that allows the isolation of faults within an item to be performed in a timely manner.
MIL-STD-2165 provides uniform procedures and methods to control planning, implementation, and verification of testability.
Testability is made up of two related practices: design for test and diagnosability.
Design for test facilitates the testing process by encouraging good design practices.
Diagnosability evaluates the ability to determine the status of an item.
This standard defines metrics related to fault detection and isolation.
Fault detection metrics are represented as a ratio of detected or detectable faults to the full set of possible faults.
The ratio is weighted using the failure rates of the faults within the fault universe.
The numbers in brackets correspond to those of the bibliography in Annex A.

Fault isolation metrics are based on a ratio of the number of faults in ambiguity groups to the total number of faults.
Isolation calculations are frequently weighted using failure rates.
Testability has been concerned with predicting and measuring the incidence of false indication.
No consensus exists in the test industry for predicting and measuring the incidence of false indication.
The standard will defer specification of metrics for false indication until such time as consensus is reached.
The standard distinguishes between two classes of metrics—predictive and empirical.
Predictive metrics include all testability and diagnosability metrics that can be derived from a static AI-ESTATE-compliant model.
Empirical metrics are derived from collected maintenance data and are beyond the scope of this standard.

All cost-related metrics are computed with respect to a single test or repair within the AI-ESTATE common element model.
All isolation metrics are computed under the assumption that no more than a single, independent fault exists at the time of diagnostics.
Isolation metrics are computed to remove dependence on diagnostic and maintenance strategies.
Detection and isolation metrics are defined to manage the complexity of computing isolation-related metrics.
The type of underlying diagnostic and maintenance strategies is not considered when defining detection and isolation metrics.

A diagnostic model establishes detectability and isolatability differently.
The diagnostic model is a fault tree model, diagnostic inference model, or enhanced diagnostic inference model.
The AI-ESTATE model defines the level entity to be the level of indenture for a particular hierarchical element.
The level entity is used for constraining diagnosis or analysis for testability and diagnosability assessment.
Many measures are defined relative to a level defined within the AI-ESTATE model.

This subclause provides the definition of each aggregation fundamental to be used in more complex metric definitions.
All fundamental measures are based on the AI-ESTATE common element model and need not be tied to specific diagnostic models (i.e., FTM, DIM, or EDIM).
Within AI-ESTATE, an action is defined by the information model to be “A specific action taken to either test or repair an item.
Actions are the primary entities against which costs are associated.
Ultimately
the diagnosis and repair process is concerned with optimizing the sequence of actions required to return a unit to service.
The function action_set returns the set of all actions within a diagnostic model at a particular level.
FUNCTION action_set (mdl : diagnostic_model; lvl : level) : SET OF action; END_FUNCTION;
Within AI-ESTATE, a diagnosis is defined by the information model to be “a lattice of diagnostic conclusions.
Typically, a diagnosis consists of failures or fault (sic.).
The diagnoses can be interconnected in a lattice to classify constituent units, e.g., by function.
This construct provides a generalized grouping mechanism for the constituents of the unit under test and their failure modes.”
The function diagnosis_set returns the set of all diagnoses within a diagnostic model at a particular level.
FUNCTION diagnosis_set (mdl : diagnostic_model; lvl : level) : SET OF diagnosis; END_FUNCTION;
Within AI-ESTATE, a failure mode is defined by the information model to be “A specific mode or means by which a unit or system can fail.
The specific failure mode is associated, first with the diagnosis, then (by way of the appropriate subtype) to the item that has failed.
The function failure_mode_set returns the set of all failure modes within a diagnostic model at a particular level.
failure modes are associated with diagnoses
level is determined by examining diagnoses
failure_mode_set returns a set of failure modes

a failure is a manifestation of an anomaly within a system

a fault is a physical cause of anomalous behavior within a system
a fault corresponds to a physical breakdown in the system
fault_set returns a set of all faults
a function is any functional behavior represented within a system
function_set returns a set of all functions
a repair item is some part of the system to be adjusted
repair_item_set returns a set of all repair items

A repair is defined by the information model to be the process undertaken to return the unit to service.
The function repair_set returns the set of all repairs within a diagnostic model at a particular level.
A resource is defined within the information model to be something that any given action in the maintenance process is likely to require to perform that action.
The function resource_set returns the set of all resources within a diagnostic model at a particular level.
The function resource_set returns the set of all resources within a diagnostic model at a particular level.
All fundamental measures are based on the AI-ESTATE common element model.
Costs are measurable quantities of time or resources.
Costs include money and/or expendables.
Cost is computed over a set of tests or repairs by using associated test action costs, repair action costs, and resource costs.
All cost calculations use the same units of measure and are based on resource cost.
No unit conversion is included in the definition.

The probability of diagnosis is computed relative to a specified set of diagnoses.

PoD is the percentage of possible diagnoses that can be detected.
PoD is described by Equation (1).

Expected percentage of detection (EPoD) is a metric.
EPoD is the failure probability-weighted percentage of possible diagnoses that can be detected.
EPoD is described by Equation (2).
Equation (2) is (2) where Di is the ith diagnosis in isld.
isld is the set returned by single_level_detection(ids, lvl).

This subclause provides definitions of testability and diagnosability metrics.
There are six isolation metrics.

The six isolation metrics are percentage of isolation, expected percentage of isolation, expected ambiguity group size, isolation effectiveness, projected effect of ambiguity upon false removals, and repair item involvement ratio.
The first and sixth of these metrics are unweighted.
The other four metrics are weighted using probability of diagnosis.
Probability of diagnosis is used to weight the four metrics.
Probability of diagnosis is used to weight expected percentage of isolation, expected ambiguity group size, isolation effectiveness, and projected effect of ambiguity upon false removals.

Isolation effectiveness is a measure of how well repair item ambiguity groups can be isolated.
Isolation effectiveness is a measure of how well repair item ambiguity groups conform to a specified diagnostic goal.
A diagnostic goal is expressed as a lower bound/minimum.
Typical diagnostic goals include the ambiguity group size or the cost/time to isolate, replace or repair ambiguity groups.
The deviation of a function of x relative to the goal y is denoted by Let.
The isolation effectiveness metric is used to measure the deviation of a function of x relative to the goal y.
The isolation effectiveness metric is used to measure the deviation of a function of x relative to the goal y for a particular level of a given diagnostic model.
The isolation effectiveness metric is used to measure the deviation of a function of x relative to the goal y for a particular level of a given diagnostic model and a specified diagnostic goal.

Projected effect of ambiguity on false removals (PEAFR) is a measure of the effect that ambiguous isolation has on the frequency of false removals
PEAFR is described by Equation (10)
AGi is the ith repair item ambiguity group
P(AGi) is the probability of repair item set (AGi)
mdl is the diagnostic model for which this metric is to be calculated
lvl is the level of the diagnostic model at which faults are to be counted
n is the total number of repair item ambiguity groups for the lvl and mdl
PEAFR gives the worst-case percentage of false removals because of diagnostic ambiguity for the specified level of the given diagnostic model
PEAFR projects the relative likelihood of false removals when malfunctions occur
The likelihood of false removals is calculated using the formula P(AGi) / (|AGi| * RT(AGi))
The formula is summed over all repair item ambiguity groups
IEEE Std 1522-2004 is a standard.
The standard is copyrighted 2005 by IEEE.
All rights to the standard are reserved by IEEE.
Ambiguity groups occur singly in the standard.
Repair item ambiguity groups are replaced as a block in the standard.
False removals can result from factors other than ineffective fault isolation.
PEAFR only quantifies the effect of diagnostic ambiguity on false removals.
PEAFR is equal to 1 minus IE with respect to isolation to a single failed repair item.
PEAFR can be calculated using the standard.
The repair item involvement ratio (RIIR) is a metric.
RIIR is the number of repair item ambiguity groups divided by the total number of ambiguity groups.
RIIR is calculated for a particular level of a given diagnostic model.
RIIR is described by Equation (11) in the standard.
AGRI is the size of the ambiguity group.
RI is the repair item for which RIIR is being calculated.
mdl is the diagnostic model for which RIIR is being calculated.

Fault detection and isolation metrics can be calculated over an entire design.
Fault detection and isolation metrics can be calculated over an explicitly defined functional subset of the design.
Typical types of subsets include functionality, technology, operational usage, and hardware source.
Typical types of subsets include operating mode, test domain, and fault universe.
Typical types of subsets include functionality, technology, operational usage, and hardware source.
Typical types of subsets include operating mode, test domain, and fault universe.
The equations defined in this clause can be used to calculate metrics for a particular functional subset.
The model (mdl) must be constructed such that only the desired subset is represented.
IEEE Std 1522-2004 is a trial-use standard for testability and fault detection and isolation metrics.
Fault detection and isolation metrics are frequently constrained by test class to calculate the fault coverage associated with different subsets of tests within the design.
Common test classes include BIT type, diagnostic usage, and test implementations.
BIT type includes startup, continuous, and periodic tests.
Diagnostic usage includes embedded diagnostics and technical manual tests.
Test implementations include current BIT, proposed BIT, and proposed technical manual tests.
When calculating metrics for a particular subset of tests within a design, equations defined in this clause can be used.
The model (mdl) must be constructed such that only the desired subset is represented.
Diagnosis failure probabilities are generally derived from failure rates.
Failure rates describe expected rates of failure over an arbitrarily long time interval.
Failure rates are most frequently expressed in terms of failures per million hours.
The same metric equation can be used to calculate EPoD and EPoI over a specific time interval.
The diagnosis failure probabilities used to calculate the EPoD and EPoI are generally derived from failure rates.
Failure rates describe expected rates of failure over an arbitrarily long time interval.
Failure rates are most frequently expressed in terms of failures per million hours.
The same metric equation can be used to calculate EPoD and EPoI over a specific time interval.
The model (mdl) must be constructed such that only the desired subset is represented.
The diagnosis failure probabilities used to calculate the EPoD and EPoI are generally derived from failure rates.
Failure rates describe expected rates of failure over an arbitrarily long time interval.
Failure rates are most frequently expressed in terms of failures per million hours.
The same metric equation can be used to calculate EPoD and EPoI over a specific time interval.
All failure rates in the specified diagnostic model (mdl) represent the number of failures expected within the given time interval.
The same metric equation can be used to calculate EPoD and EPoI over a specific time interval.
The model (mdl) must be constructed such that only the desired subset is represented.

The product life cycle process is related to diagnostic analysis and design.
A comprehensive diagnostic analysis and design program requires a dedicated effort.
The diagnostic design life cycle is organized around five phases.
The five phases are: Requirements definition, Architecture design, Detailed test design, Verification and validation, and Diagnostic maturation.
A brief description of each phase is provided in B.1–B.7.
The first step in an effective testability program is to define a complete set of requirements.
Diagnostic requirements are typically expressed in performance terms.
Diagnostic requirements should express the desired outcome without directing how to achieve it.
Goals are typically specified around fault detection, fault isolation, and fault isolation resolution or operational isolation.
Mission reliability is a related requirement examined early in the design phase.
Mission reliability is used to verify the reliability of systems that can be reconfigured, redundant, or safety-critical.
Mission reliability is being applied as a measure of prognostic capability to satisfy mission requirements with a satisfactory measure of confidence.
System prognostics are shown analytically to be capable of predicting some interval over which the system will operate without malfunction.
System-level metrics may be specified at this time, including mean time between failure and operational availability.
Derivative requirements include mean time to repair, maintenance frequency, and skill levels of repair personnel.
Customer warranties may be executed on some metrics such as mean time between failure or operational availability.
IEEE Std 1522-2004 is a standard.
The standard is copyrighted by IEEE.
The standard is about diagnostic characteristics and metrics.
The standard is from 2004.
The standard has a copyright notice.
The standard is reserved by IEEE.
The architecture design phase is in the standard.
The intent in the architecture design phase is to develop a preliminary design framework.
The framework allows diagnostic program requirements to be allocated in a top-down manner.
The diagnostic program requirements are allocated to physical system components.
A basic diagnostic subsystem architecture is laid out in the standard.
The architecture is laid out in conjunction with trade studies.
Subsystem requirements are allocated to individual hardware elements.
The requirements are allocated to drive detailed design requirements.
System-level testability models are created to support the analysis.
The models are created in conjunction with a functional failure modes, effects and criticality analysis.
Testability analysis is performed on the models of the design.
The analysis is performed in a top-down manner.
The analysis verifies that the functional/physical partitioning and diagnostic requirements allocation will satisfy the top-level requirements.
The analysis uses the same metrics as identified in B.1.
The analysis provides guidance for diagnostic design influence.
The diagnostic design features necessary to meet testability requirements are identified and incorporated into the product design.
An elementary framework for a test strategy begins to emerge during the analysis.
The framework emerges during the diagnostic design influence process.
The detailed test design phase is in the standard.
The purpose of the detailed test design phase is to develop a detailed design solution.
The solution meets all diagnostic program requirements.
Detailed hardware and software designs are created in accordance with allocated system requirements.
The physical design matures during the phase.
The hardware aspects are reflected in the analysis models.
The hardware aspects are linked to their functional elements.
The basic diagnostic subsystem architecture is modified as design and support system details emerge.
Diagnostic and reliability trade studies are iterated as required.
The results of the modifications are reflected in the models and verified.
The modifications affect cost, weight, power, MTBCF, and MTBF.
The allocations of FD, FI, and FIR are adjusted as necessary.
Diagnostic and reliability trade studies are iterated as required.
The studies affect cost, weight, power, MTBCF, and MTBF.
The allocations of FD, FI, and FIR are adjusted as necessary.
The results of the modifications are reflected in the models and verified.
The modifications are reflected in the analysis models.
The modifications are linked to their functional elements.
The basic diagnostic subsystem architecture is modified as design and support system details emerge.
Diagnostic and reliability trade studies are iterated as required.
The studies affect cost, weight, power, MTBCF, and MTBF.
The allocations of FD, FI, and FIR are adjusted as necessary.
The results of the modifications are reflected in the models and verified.
The modifications are reflected in the analysis models.
Preliminary test verticality is performed during this phase.
Results of this analysis are comparative margins and tolerances of the tests.
Preliminary test verticality includes BIT vs. ATE test consistency.
Preliminary test verticality includes factory vs. field test consistency.
Preliminary test verticality includes worst-case tolerance variations.
Preliminary test verticality includes latent manufacturing defects.
Verification and validation phase validates detailed design solution.
Verification and validation phase validates compliance with specification requirements.
Verification and validation phase validates achievement of diagnostic requirements on delivery.
This approach uses test and demonstration to verify built-in test operations.
Diagnostic support equipment and support system contributions to diagnostics are tested or demonstrated.
Quantitative testability allocations and design requirements are verified through analysis and inspection methods.
Validity of fault detection and fault isolation models are assessed through static fault insertion.
Susceptibility to false alarms and can not duplicates is evaluated during field testing opportunities.
Diagnostic software only performs its intended job in the presence of failures.
Fault insertion is the only controlled opportunity for exercising embedded hardware/software design.
Diagnostic software must be executed to verify tests assumed during analysis phases were implemented in software.
Faults selected for insertion should be chosen based on highest failure probability.
Faults selected for insertion should be chosen based on maximum amount of diagnostic software exercised.
Faults selected for insertion should be chosen based on least potential damage to the unit under test.
Fault insertion is accomplished by physically inserting nondestructive faults into hardware design.
Faults inserted are properly detected and reported.
Diagnostic software must be executed to verify tests assumed during analysis phases were implemented in software.
Corrective actions for FD/FI deficiencies are to be implemented and validated.
False alarms and can not duplicates are undesirable design characteristics.
False alarms and can not duplicates cannot truly be predicted or systematically tested.
Risk reduction activities can be performed in conjunction with other activities to mitigate the risk incurred by the possibility of false alarms and can not duplicates.
Development and qualification tests exercise the hardware under simulated environmental and life conditions.
Anomalies can be corrected in a “test, analyze, and fix” methodology.
Specification compliance cannot truly be evaluated.
Laboratory and field tests provide an opportunity to correct diagnostic anomalies.
The purpose of the maturation phase is to implement a program that effectively measures actual product performance.
A maturation plan must be constructed to document how data indicative of diagnostics performance will be collected, measured, evaluated, and acted on.
The diagnostic design must meet the diagnostic and health management requirements.
Unexpected and unplanned system-level design interactions can degrade the performance of the diagnostic design.
Remedial actions must be taken when degradation results in unacceptable product performance or other cost of ownership problems.
Laboratory and field tests are performed using simulated or actual interfaces.
Diagnostic anomalies can be corrected in laboratory and field tests.
The purpose of the maturation phase is to implement a program that effectively measures actual product performance.
A maturation plan must be constructed to document how data indicative of diagnostics performance will be collected, measured, evaluated, and acted on.
The diagnostic design must meet the diagnostic and health management requirements.
Unexpected and unplanned system-level design interactions can degrade the performance of the diagnostic design.
Remedial actions must be taken when degradation results in unacceptable product performance or other cost of ownership problems.
Root cause analysis must be performed to identify potential adjustments, improvements, or refinements to diagnostic, support, or operational elements.
The maturation phase begins at the conceptual design stage and continues throughout the system life cycle.
A maturation plan must be constructed to document how data indicative of diagnostics performance will be collected, measured, evaluated, and acted on.
The diagnostic design must meet the diagnostic and health management requirements.
Unexpected and unplanned system-level design interactions can degrade the performance of the diagnostic design.
Remedial actions must be taken when degradation results in unacceptable product performance or other cost of ownership problems.
Root cause analysis must be performed to identify potential adjustments, improvements, or refinements to diagnostic, support, or operational elements.
Authorized licensed use limited to: Technische Universitat Kaiserslautern.
The diagnostic design is demonstrated to meet the diagnostic and health management requirements at the completion of the validation phase.
The diagnostic design is fielded and starts to be used in an operational environment.
Unexpected and unplanned system-level design interactions, operational and environmental stresses, and other influences can degrade the performance of the diagnostic design.
Remedial actions must be taken when degradation results in unacceptable product performance or other cost of ownership problems.
IEEE Std 1522-2004 is a standard.
The standard is copyrighted by IEEE.
The standard is from 2004.
The standard has annex C.
Annex C is normative.
Annex C contains extensions to the AI-ESTATE standard.
The AI-ESTATE standard is required by the probability_of_diagnosis and probability_of_repair_item_set measures.
The AI-ESTATE standard is defined within IEEE Std 1232-2002.
The AI-ESTATE standard allows a failure rate value to be assigned to each diagnosis.
The AI-ESTATE standard is extended in annex C.
The extension redefines the diagnosis entity in the common element model.
The common element model is defined within IEEE Std 1232-2002.
The AI-ESTATE common element model is used in the extension.
The extension is for the failure rate entity.
The failure rate entity is a subtype of the failure_rate entity.
The failure_rate entity is in the AI-ESTATE common element model.
The failure_rate entity has a subtype called EXTEND_failure_rate.
EXTEND_failure_rate is an abstract entity.
EXTEND_failure_rate is a subtype of the failure_rate entity.
EXTEND_failure_rate contains the frequency value for the associated failure rate.
EXTEND_failure_rate has two subtypes: EXTEND_weibull_failure_rate and EXTEND_exponential_failure_rate.
EXTEND_failure_rate is a subtype of the failure_rate entity.
EXTEND_failure_rate is in the AI-ESTATE common element model.
EXTEND_failure_rate contains the frequency value for the associated failure rate.
EXTEND_failure_rate has a subtype called EXTEND_weibull_failure_rate.
EXTEND_weibull_failure_rate is a subtype of the EXTEND_failure_rate entity.
EXTEND_weibull_failure_rate is used when the associated failure rate is the result of a Weibull distribution.
EXTEND_weibull_failure_rate has two attributes: alpha and beta.
IEEE Std 1522-2004 is a standard for testability and trial-use.
The standard is copyrighted by IEEE.
The standard is from 2005.
The standard has attribute definitions.
The attribute definitions are for the associated_frequency attribute.
The associated_frequency attribute is used to specify the rate of failures associated with a diagnosis.
The associated_frequency attribute is used over a given time span.
EXTEND_weibull_failure_rate is a subtype of the EXTEND_failure_rate entity.
EXTEND_weibull_failure_rate has two attributes: alpha and beta.
beta is a REAL.
beta is an attribute.
alpha is an attribute.
alpha is used to specify the alpha parameter of the Weibull distribution.
beta is used to specify the beta parameter of the Weibull distribution.
EXTEND_exponential_failure_rate is a subtype of EXTEND_failure_rate.
EXTEND_exponential_failure_rate is used when the associated failure rate is the result of an exponential distribution.
EXTEND_exponential_failure_rate is a subtype of EXTEND_failure_rate.
EXTEND_exponential_failure_rate is used when the associated failure rate is the result of an exponential distribution.
EXTEND_diagnosis is a subtype of diagnosis.
EXTEND_diagnosis contains the failure rate for the associated diagnosis.
new_rate is an attribute.
new_rate is used to specify the failure rate associated with the given diagnosis.
